comments:
If you open a site.xml that has a feature with an "invalid" qualifier string, you get exception as you try to use the editor. This happens because we have a token that we replace at build time as a qualifier string, namely @TOKEN@ as for example in:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<site>
   <description>
	 bla bla
   </description>
   <feature url="features/foo.bar.baz_5.0.0.@RELEASE@.jar" id="foo.bar.baz" version="5.0.0.@RELEASE@" os="linux,macosx,win32" ws="carbon,gtk,win32">
      <category name="cat1"/>
   </feature>
   <category-def name="cat1" label="cat1">
      <description>
         Bla bla baz.
      </description>
   </category-def>
</site>


-- Error Log --

got rid of the exceptions.  I believe there is another bug opened about referencing plug-ins/features version which will be created dynamically, but don't know the number off the top of my head.

btw Eddy, I highly recommend using something like major.minor.service.qualifier as your versioning for your plug-ins. For example, 1.0.0.qualifier, where qualifier is something that PDE Build will replace it with what you desire.

Please see the docs about this:
http://help.eclipse.org/help33/topic/org.eclipse.pde.doc.user/guide/tasks/pde_version_qualifiers.htm

Thank you for using PDE :D

> btw Eddy, I highly recommend using something like major.minor.service.qualifier
> as your versioning for your plug-ins. For example, 1.0.0.qualifier, where
> qualifier is something that PDE Build will replace it with what you desire.
> 

In this situation, this site.xml is a file we run elsewhere in our build system, hence the @TOKEN@ thing (just to make it safer for an ant task). We definitely use .qualifier in anything PDE!
